docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: This guide is created to help you get started with GitHub, a version control system (VCS) that is widely popular among software developers managing projects of all sizes. GitHub allows developers to back-up, share, and extend their software projects, opening doors for version tracking and collaboration between developers.

docs.title: Who is this guide for?
docs.text: This guide is for anyone with no experience with GitHub using either a Linux-based operating system (MacOS, Ubuntu, etc.) or a Windows machine.

docs.title: After following this guide, you will be able to
docs.text:
1. Create a new code repository
  2. Fork another user's existing repository
  3. Clone the repository in GitHub into your local machine

docs.title: Pre-requisites
docs.text:
1. A computer running Windows, MacOS, or a Linux distribution.
  2. A working internet connection
  3. A browser
  4. git
  5. A GitHub account

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Cloning is essentially creating a copy of the repository hosted somewhere else, in this case GitHub, to the local machine. It enables tracking and synchronisation of the hosted version and the local version.

This page contains the steps to clone a GitHub repository. It covers cloning via the terminal or a JetBrains IDE. By the end of the page, you should be able to modify and extend the repository locally.

docs.title: In Your Browser
docs.text:
1. Go to the desired repository in GitHub. The URL of the browser must be in the following format: 
    https://github.com/[owner-name]/[repository-name]
    If you would like to create your own repository or fork an existing one, see Creating a New Repository and Forking an Existing Repository.
  2. In the repository page, click the green "<> Code" button. A dropdown should pop showing options for cloning.
  3. Focusing on the "Local" option.

  4. Click on "HTTPS".

  5. Copy the URL to your clipboard by clicking or pressing Ctrl+C (Windows, Linux) or +C (MacOS).

  6. Open a terminal in the directory for the local copy's destination.
  7. Copy the link into your clipboard.

Note

If you are cloning [repository-name] into the [destination] directory, the resulting file structure will be [destination]/[repository-name]

docs.title: In Your Local Computer
docs.text:
via the terminalvia a JetBrains IDE
  1. Open a terminal in the parent directory that you want to clone into.
  2. In the terminal, type git clone.
  3. Paste the URL into the terminal. The full command should look like the following: 
    git clone https://github.com/[owner-name]/[repository-name].git
  4. Press Enter.
  1. Close the current project by clicking > "File" > "Close Project". This should take you into the home page.

  2. Click "Projects" > "Clone Repository".

  3. Paste the URL into the top text bar.

  4. Press Enter or click "Clone" to proceed to cloning.

Success

A copy of the repository under should now appear in the directory the repository is cloned into.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: In this page, you have learned how to clone a repository using the terminal or a JetBrains IDE. The repository should now be open for modification or extension in your computer. To submit changes into GitHub, see Pushing commits to a remote repository from the official GitHub docs.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Repository is a centralized storage location, often a folder or directory, where developers store and manage a project's source code, allowing for collaboration, version control, and tracking of changes.

This page covers how to create a repository and how to change a private repository to public.

  1. Go to Github following the link below: 

    https://github.com

  2. Once you are on Github, go to the top right corner and Click on the '+' sign:

  3. Click on New repository

  4. Set your repository name under Repository name

  5. Set your repository to Private.

Warning

Unless you want to share your code with others, it is generally recommended to set your repository Private. You can always change it to Public when needed.

If you need a guide on how to change your Private repository to Public, check 'How to change it to public?' section below.

Next StepHow to change it to public?
  1. Check 'Add a README file'

Note

It is recommended to include README file on your project as it provides essential information for users to understand what your project does, how to use it, and any other relevant details

  1. Click on 'Create repository'

  2. Your new repository has been created. The lock symbol next to your username shows that it’s set to private. You’ll also notice the README file has been generated.

Success

Your new repository is successfully created.

  1. Navigate to the repository you’d like to switch from private to public.

  2. Go to settings

  3. In the settings, scroll down to the bottom until you find the Danger Zone section.

  4. Click on 'Change visibility'

  5. Click on 'Change to public'

  6. Click on 'I want to make this repository to public'

  7. Click on 'I have read and understand these effects'

  8. Click on 'Make this repository public'

  9. Once it redirects you back to settings, it means you have succcessfully changed the visibility setting to public.

Success

Private repository is now changed to public.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: In this page, you have learned how to create a new repository and how to change a private repository to public. The repository should now be open for modification or extension in your computer. To submit changes into GitHub, see Pushing commits to a remote repository from the official GitHub docs.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Just as you’d fork a piece of food to pick it up, you can fork someone else’s repository to create your own copy. It allows you to modify the code without affecting the original repository, giving you freedom to experiment it as much as you can.

This page helps you how to fork a repository.

  1. Go to the desired repository in GitHub. The URL of the browser must be in the following format: 

    https://github.com/[owner-name]/[repository-name]

  2. Navigate to the repository you want to fork from.

  3. Click on "Fork".

  4. Click on "Create a new fork".

  5. After step 3, you’ll see that the repository name is automatically set to the original name. You can adjust it to something that better fits your needs.

  6. Under "Owner", click an owner for the forked repository.

  7. You can also include an optional description for additional context.

  8. Click on "Create fork"

  9. You will be redirected to this page while the repository is being forked to your GitHub account.

  10. The repository has been successfully forked.

Success

The repository has been successfully forked.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: In this page, you have learned how to fork someone else's repository. Forking gives you the freedom to experiment and modify the code without affecting the original project, enabling you to work independently or contribute back via pull requests. With your fork successfully created, you can now make changes locally, push commits to your fork, and collaborate further. For more detailed guidance, refer to the How to fork a repository on the offical GitHub website.

docs.title: Glossary
docs.text: Terms Definition Version Control System Abbreviated as VCS, it is any system that keeps track of constantly-changing software source code. git A command-line VCS program to organise source versions locally. GitHub A hosting service for open-source projects. Users can share and create extended versions of other user's projects. Local Machine Your own computer. Something that's directly interacting with the user. Fork (verb) Create your own copy in GitHub of another user's repository. Clone (verb) Copy a repository somewhere in the local machine. Clone (noun) A copy of a repository in the local machine.
